pageContext.desc: On his government survey to mark a route from Missouri to Santa Fe in 1825.
pageContext.category: Everett D. Graff Collection of Western Americana; U.S. Western Expansion; Diaries

pages.transcription:
Saturday July 16, 1825
page torn Brown? commenced
page torn the road at Fort
page torn one mile and 3/4
[page torn]] from the
page torn and pursued
page torn south west direction -- crossed Little
Blue about 4 miles above its junction
with the Missouri -- The ford is rocky --
In descending to the ford one of our
waggons upset -- sustained but little injury --
We halted at a beautiful spring &
encamped for the night having traveled
8 miles -- This is a very rich & fertile country
and finely watered -- our general course to day
S. 76 West

Monday 18  In addition to our ?
party there are several of page torn
? settlers, accompany page torn
-ough? the Blue Country for? page torn
of selecting land -- the page torn
first quality & the Indian page torn
just been page torn ?
of it may be anticipated as page torn
it is brought into market -- We met
with nothing to impede our progress to
day -- Bohons horse was bit by a rattlesnake,
which detained him a few hours
the horse was soon cured & encamped at
a small grove on the right, upwards
of 11 miles from our last emcampment --
Killed a heif this evening -- general course
to day S. 35 1/4 W.

Tuesday 19 -- Remained in camp
for the purpose of drying our
Beef and making some repairs
to the waggons -- exchanged horses
with one of the persons that accompanied us
from the settlements -- a small party of
Sock? Indians page torn us?
Wednesday 20 We pursued our route
to the big Blue a distance of 5 1/4
miles -- The bluff which we were compelled
to descend is steep & verry
rocky -- The waggons got down safe
The ford is a good one 20 miles (supposed)
above the mouth -- The country
here is broken, sterile and rocky -- unfit 
for cultivation for some distance each
side of the river -- We however soon struck

the prairies, which were high
and of good soil -- the prospect
commanding -- From the Big
blue to the State line the distance
is 4 3/4 miles -- The distance of this
days travel page torn -- We crossed the
State line (of Missouri) on? Latitude
39.00.20 - Longitude W 94.17. page torn
and about 9 miles south of the Kansas River
-- a short distance to our right and within
the limits of Missouri, passed an Indian
village which proved to be a temporary settlement of a small party
of socks -- Col. Reeves, Mr Gamble and
some of our men went to it and were
friendly received -- We encamped at a
small grove on our left -- some 15 or

20 of the Indians visited our encampment,
and were presented with
a small quantity of Tobacco --
Genl course to day S. 71 1/2 W
Thursday 21 Our route to day is
through an extensive prairie --
generally upon the dividing ridge
of the Big Blue & Kansas -- one of
the hunters (? the old?) killed a deer --
We encamped after travelling 13 1/4
miles in time to repair one of our
waggon tongues -- The flies have been
so bad to day that the horses are
much cut down -- genl course 
S. 70 W --
Friday 22 -- Set out early and
travelled 9 miles -- The flies continue

to annoy us very much -- Breakfasted
and remained during the day --
This morning we intersected the
waggon road of the Santa Fee traders,
who went out in the spring -- They
had gone round the head of the Bluer -- We
are now opposite the source of the
Big Blue -- The country is quite high
almost entirely prairie, only a
few scattering trees -- scarcely a
grove within the eyes reach of more
than an acre or two in extent, and
badly watered -- The soil of a midling
quality -- genl. course S. 26 1/2 W. --
In consequence of the flies we
resolved to travel in the night
as the moon now affords light --

Saturday 23 We travelled last night from
sun down 'till 10 o clock turned
out our horses and lay down
in the prairie without pitching our
tents -- rose at sunrise and pursued
our journey -- encamped at 9 oclk
AM.  Mr Brown, who with the
surveying party had remained at
yesterdays camp 'till this morning
came up about 11 oclk -- distance
14 miles -- general course
Sunday 24 We again set out just
before sun down last evening and had
not proceeded far before it became
dark, the clouds most of the time
obscured the light of the moon and we

missed the trail and lost our
way -- Finding ourselves in a
deep ravine or hollow we halted
for the purpose of making an examination
of the country on our right
and left, with the hope of finding
the dividing ridge between the
Kansas & Osage waters, on which
our route lay -- Just as the
hindmost waggon came up and
stopped, two of the men who had
borne off to the right some time
before came up in great haste
with the cry of Indians!  Indians!
The alarm was so sudden that
it produced some little confusion

for a moment -- The report of the
men that came in was that they
had fallen in with a large
party of Indians, two or three of whom
had chased them some distance --
Believing that if they should prove
hostile, the surveying party, who
had remained behind for the purpose
of bringing up the survey in the 
morning, might be troubled by them,
Col. Reeves & Capt. Cooper with most
of the men immediately went in
pursuit of them -- I remained with
the waggons for the purpose of placing 
them in a proper posture of defence --
Col. R. had not pursued more
than two or three miles before he

discovered that the party consisted
of Spaniards & our own country
men who were returning from
Santa Fee -- They had been badly treated
by the Osage Indians a party
of whom they fell in with on the
Arkansas & who robbed them of 120 mules &
Horses -- Like our men they also believed
us to be Indians & gave
the first pursuit under that
impression -- The manner in which
our men fled only tended to confirm
that belief, & when our party 
which went in pursuit of them
came in sight they in turn fled --
They soon discovered their mistake
and halted -- mutual explanations

took place & the affair turned 
out to be a matter of amusement
Their party encamped with our
surveying party & the opportunity
of sending in communications was
improved by those of the latters & of
the pursuing party who felt thus
disposed -- Cap Cooper returned to
us about 10 oclk in company with
a Spaniard & one of the American adventurers --
Those of us who had remained
with the waggons were gratified to learn
that the affair had ended so differently
from what was at first anticipated --
I enquired of the American if any

intelligence had been recd at
Santa Fee via Mexico relative to
the war upon which we were
engaged -- He informed me there
was none; But that an agent from
the Mexican Government was in
the company he had just left, &
that his business was relative to
the intercourse between the two
countries -- Thinking that this
person might have some authority
from his government to negotiate
relative to a road, I concluded
'tho late at night to ride to their
camp a distance of about 3 miles

and see him -- On my arrival
I found that Col. Reeves had
been introduced to him & communicated
with him on the subject
of his mission -- The gentleman
himself whose name is Manuel
Escutharo had retired to rest and
there was no motive for disturbing
him, inasmuch as Col Reeves
had ascertained that he
was not authorized to make
any definite arrangement
on the subject of our mission --
We returned to camp & after dispatching
half of one our ? to the ?

found from an observation this 
evening that we are now in Lat.
38.46.51 -- distance from our last
encampment 15 1/2 miles general course
The country continues much
as last described, almost entirely
high & rolling prairies, with an
occasional skirt of timber extremely
narrow, so much so as to preclude
the remotest idea of its ever
being settled -- These skirts of timber
are on our right & left, being on 
the branches which make 
from the ridge to the rivers
Osage & Kansas

Wednesday 27.  After much consultation
between Col Reeves & myself
it was resolved to dispatch Mr
Gamble to the Osage village, for
the purpose of making an arrangement
with those Indians for a meeting
at some other point than their
own village, where we had intended
to have treated with them
Mr G. will if possible make an arrangement
with them to meet us
at the Kaw Spring near the
Arkansas -- The reason which induced
this measure, was the utter
impossibility of proceeding to their

village (which is 80 miles out
of our route) in consequence
of the flies, with the expedition
as we had first intended -- Mr G. is
also instructed in case he may be
able to make the desired arrangement
with the Osages, to proceed to the Kansas?
village and make a like arrangement
with them for a meeting -- Mr G.
with three of the men accordingly set
out this morning with a view to
accomplish these objects --
Thursday 28 We left camp last night
and proceeded 'till 10 oclock when we halted
in the prairie & stretched ourselves

on our blankets 'till nearly day
light this morning when we again
set out and travelled 'till 8 oclk
just as we were getting under way
last night we discovered that two
?, which we had taken from
the settlements, had left us -- As they
had given us much trouble, and
the prospect of game being better
than we had anticipated through
this part of our route, we did not
pursue them -- one of the young
men discovered a male & gave pursuit,
he was so wild that it was impossible to
take him -- The appearance of

the country continues as last described --
during the day it rained sufficiently
to check the flies and
we again set out at 4? P.M. &
and proceeded through a very beautiful
country to a creek, leaving
the dividing ridge, which we
have for some time pursued
to our right -- In descending
to this encampment the scenery
is truly sublime -- We encamped
on this creek haveing
travelled since last night 21 miles --
general course
Friday 29  The rain had dissipated

the flies to such a degree this
morning that we were able to
pursue our journey without
much molestation from them
nine miles from last nights camp
we came to creek of considerable size
where we rested for a few hours -- This
is a branch of the Osage river -- The
party that went from Franklin to
Santa Fee last spring had thrown
a bridge across the creek and
expedited our crossing considerably.
We marked a tree on the bank
"distance to Fort Osage 119 miles" -- We
left this place at 4 pm. & travelled

4 3/4 miles to another creek of
considerable size and encamped
for the night having made 13 3/4
miles -- The soil and general appearance
of the country is much 
better for the last 20 miles than
we have passed for some time,
there are many groves of
timber in different directions
& an abundance of water
-- general course
Saturday 30.  After experiencing
one of the most tremendous gales
& alarming thunderstorm, during
allmost the whole night, we set out

this morning early and proceeded
some distance before breakfast
the soil continues of a good
quality & the groves of timber
& streams of water are sufficient
to admit of some settlements --
As we were about entering?
our journey to day, one of the
waggon tongues gave way & we
were compelled to encamp for the
night -- distance to day 2 miles -- 
genl course
Sunday 31.  We travelled to day
through a fine country of land
passing two or three creeks of 
running water, the banks of which

as well as the small water course
have considerable timber such
as Walnut, Hackberry, Elm &
sometimes oak -- Encamped on
one of these having travelled 10 ?
miles - genl. course
Monday August 1.  Set out
early & travelled over a beautiful
prairie, in descending 
to a creek, some of us who 
were in advance of the
waggons discovered some Elk
near it -- pursuit was made
& three of them taken --
we encamped for the purpose

of drying our meats -- We
named this creek the Elk fork of
the Osage & marked upon a
large tree "distance to fort
Osage 140 miles -- Bohon was
accidentally wounded just below
the knee with an axe by one
of the men & I fear badly -- The
Lattitude at this place is 38o.41.52
variation of the needle 11o.38' E dis 2 3/4
miles
Tuesday 2  Our Horses requiring
rest, we remained in camp this
day --
Wednesday 3  This morning Maj.
Sibley who had been detained
at Fort Osage came up with

us -- our horses not being sufficiently 
rested & Col Reeves
being somewhat unwell we
remained in camp this day
Thursday 4.  Set out early & travelled
over a high prairie -- soil 2d & 3d qy
at about 8 oclock stopped for
breakfast on a small creek --
rocky bottom -- supposed to
be a branch of the Nee-ozho
-- continued our journey
over a high, rolling, flinty &
rocky prairie -- as we were ascending
one of the hills we met one of
the young men who had

accompanied Mr Gamble to
the Osage villages & who
had been dispatched from
there by him with the
gratifying intelligence that
the chiefs & head men of
the Osages would meet us
on the Neeozho -- we encamped
upon a branch of
that river having travelled
13 miles -- Genl course
Friday 5 We renewed our journey
at an early hour and reached
the Neeozho in a distance
of 6 3/4 miles over the same

kind of flinty prairie as yesterday --
Here we encamped for the purpose of treating with
the Indians, as we expect them
in the course of two or three
days -- Genl. course
Saturday 6 -- We have named 
this place "council grove"  It 
is a beautiful situation and
calculated for considerable
settlements -- a spring is discovered
in the prairie but a little
distance from our camp &
the range for our horses is
excellent -- Mercury in Farenheit
Thermometer at sunset 86"

The country does not seem
to abound in game, probably
from the circumstance of the
Indians frequently ranging
here -- We however procure without
much difficulty a sufficiency 
of deer & Elk meat --
Sunday 7  Two of the young
men to day while hunting
discovered a small party of Indians
one of whom came to them --
It was not ascertained to what
nation they belong, but we
presume that they are a hunting
party, either of the Osages or Kansas

the village of the former being
on this river about 80 miles south
East of this place & that of the
latter on the Kansas River about
forty miles north of this --
Monday 8 -- Mr Gamble arrived
at our camp this evening with
40 Indians of the Great & Little
Osages & Mr W. S. Williams an
Interpreter -- They encamped
within a few rods of us & were
informed that we would hold a
council with them tomorrow --
Tuesday 9 -- We had a conference
with the Indians

and Mr Sibley on the part of
the Commissioners explained to them
the views of our government
relative to the road through their
country & that we had called
them to us for the purpose
of procuring their consent to
the marking & uninterrupted
use of the road -- And further,
proposed to give them in consideration
of their acceding by treaty to our proposition
$300 in merchandise at the
signing thereof and $500 payable
in St Louis or at Chouteaus trading
house near they village -- After

some consultation several of them
replied, commencing with the
chief of the G. Osages -- all of them
expressed their assent to the proposition
and their willingness to
execute the treaty -- we separated
for the purpose of preparing the
papers to hold another council
tomorrow --
Wednesday 10 To day the Indians
were again assembled with us in
council and after minutely explaining
to them through the
Interpreter each article of the
treaty it was signed by the Commsr

and chiefs & the head men of the
great & Little Osages & the mdse
given to them as stipulated
all seeming satisfied with the
arrangement -- It being necessary
to take an Interpreter with us
and not as yet haveing employed
any, we hired Williams at the
rate of $400 a year, to accompany
us --
Thursday 11  After dispatching
our Interpreter to the Kansas village
for the purpose of procuring a
meeting with that nation at some
convenient place on our route

we again struck our tents and
proceeded on our journey -- In
a short distance we discovered a
large gang of Elk -- After a long
chace five of them were killed --
We passed no timber to day and
but one little run of water -- We
travelled 16 1/2 miles and came
to a few scattering trees and a
small branch of water, where
we encamped & soon had the
good fortune to discover one of the
finest springs I most ever beheld -- It
was a great luxury -- The prairies

are becomeing more extensive,
and, timber & water scarce -- soil
of inferior quality ---
Friday 12 -- It was concluded 
to leave this spring without drying
our meat -- It was therefore for the
most part thrown away, with the
expectation that we shall meet with
Buffalo in a day or two -- we travelled
through an allmost boundless prairie
an in about 10 miles found a little
water & two or three cotton wood trees,
-- beleiving we might within a
reasonable distance, find better
accommodations for an encampment
we proceeded, but to our dissapointment

after travelling 10 1/2 miles farther
making 20 1/2 miles we were
compelled to encamp on a
small creek, with but one
solitary cotton wood tree, this
was cut down and furnished
wood for cooking -- Genl course
Saturday 13 -- Dispatched
an additional number of
hunters in advance & set out
at an early hour -- we reached 
in the distance of nine miles
a creek of considerable size & a
grove of cotton woods -- This stream
is supposed to be the Cotton Wood
fork of the Neeozho -- on

our arrival at the grove we
found the Hunters had got in
but with no game -- pitched
our tents for the night -- There
had been a short time since a
large body of Indians encamped
at this place -- supposed to be
the Osages returning from their
Buffalo Hunt -- a deer came in
sight of our camp and was taken
by our hunters -- this served us
for meat -- The winds are very 
high during the day & night -- Is it
usual?  For two or three nights
there has been no dew -- Genl
course

Sunday 14 -- A remarkably
cool morning -- We set out
after an early Breakfast
and passed over a beautiful
prairie -- No timber in sight
and no appearance of water
for a long distance -- We
crossed the dividing ridge
between Neeozho & Little Arkasas
Encamped on a small creek
in the open prairie -- Buffaloe
manure our only fuel -- distance
20 miles Genl. course
The scarcity of timber &
water has been such for this

and some three or four preceeding
days that we have
been compelled to make long
stages -- our horses are sensibly
affected by it, and many are
on the point of failing entirely --
Just after dark our Interpreter
came up with two Kansas
Indians, haveing left some
four or five miles behind
forty or fifty more of that
nation -- They will join us
to morrow, but we shall be
compelled to proceed 'till we find
timber, before we can treat
with them

Monday 15 Left our encampment
at an early hour
-- Capt Cooper thinking that
the hunters might get into the
Buffalo range to day -- went with
the hunters & I remained in
charge of the waggons in his place
-- We had proceeded but a few
miles before the Indians came
up -- They manifested great
impatience, and expressed a
strong wish for us to turn
to our left three or four miles
where a grove of timber was 
disernable -- I assented and
on reaching it found Col. R &
Maj. S. with the hunting party

they had been several
miles on the trail &
finding no appearance of
timber returned to this
place -- Here we pitched
our tents & the Indians
also encamped -- This evening
held a talk with the
Indians who readily assented to
our proposition, which was similar
to the one made to the
Osages, and likewise expressed
their joy that such a measure
as the marking a road
in the vicinity of their villages
was in progress -- distance 13 m
genl course

There were 57 Kansas &
two Otloes -- We made some
small presents to the latter
Teusday 16  This
morning the Indians were
assembled and the chiefs and
head men signed the treaty
after it was duly explained
to the whole party in council
assembled -- The merchandise
was delivered to them & an
order for Five Hundred dollars
worth more on Messr Curtis &
Ely -- These Indians I suspect
have not been so
much in the habit of receiving

presents & annuities as the
Osages, as they had considerable
strife and excitement
relative to the distribution
-- on the other hand the Osages
proceeded with the most perfect
regularity in their division &
all were satisfied -- They appointed
two distributors, and these made
an equitable division -- The remainder
had nothing to say -- After concluding
our business we departed,
leaving the Indians disputing
about their goods -- We
took our course for the
Arkansas without reference
to the trace of Santa Fee

traders, which we had
followed most of the way
and which was now considerably
to our right -- We
reached the little arkansas &
encamped -- Our hunters came
in haveing killed severall
Bull Buffaloes -- The meat
they brought in was of inferior
quality, the animal being
poor at this season of the year
The cows are said to be fine --
we expect to be among them
in a day or two -- distance
12 1/2 miles -- The country
through which we passed to
